Introduction

Aging is a universal process characterized by a gradual loss of functional reserve across multiple organ systems.  From a molecular perspective, aging is due to accumulated genomic and metabolic insults that impair homeostasis.  These changes lead to cellular dysfunction, tissue changes, and eventually, clinically apparent organ system decline.  To properly care for older adults, clinicians must distinguish between physiologic aging and pathologic conditions.

Mechanisms

Aging involves the gradual buildup of molecular damage that interferes with cell function.  Although several experimental interventions (eg, senolytic agents) are under investigation, no clinically approved therapy has been shown to slow, halt, or reverse these fundamental mechanisms.

Molecular events

  • Genomic damage:  The average human cell sustains roughly 100,000 DNA lesions per day from environmental insults, endogenous free radicals, and natural replication errors.  With advancing age, DNA damage (eg, base oxidation) increases, and DNA repair (eg, base excision repair, mismatch repair) capacity declines, leading to a greater chance of mutations.
  • Mitochondrial dysfunction:  Electron transport chain function (eg, mitochondrial DNA mutations) deteriorates with age, leading to a drop in ATP efficiency and an increase in reactive oxygen species production.  The NAD‚Å∫ pool declines because it is regenerated less efficiently within mitochondria, which impairs antioxidant enzymes and further limits DNA repair.
  • Proteostatic stress:  Cells invest heavily in proper protein folding and in the clearing of misfolded or damaged proteins.  With age, the folding machinery (chaperones) declines, causing misfolded proteins to accumulate, activating stress responses (initially prosurvival but later proapoptotic).  In parallel, the cell's waste disposal pathways (ubiquitin-proteasome, autophagy-lysosome) slow down because their components are damaged by oxidation.  A brownish residue called lipofuscin (aggregates or proteins, lipids, and iron) accumulates in lysosomes, serving as a marker of cellular waste buildup (
    image 1
    ).
  • Extracellular matrix cross-linking:  Extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins constantly undergo random glycation, whereby sugar molecules covalently bind to their amino groups (ie, Maillard reaction).  Unlike regulated enzymatic glycosylation, this process serves no physiologic purpose.  Over time, these reactions form advanced glycation end products (AGEs), which are stable and generally irreversible protein modifications.  Concurrent oxidation (glycoxidation) can result in cross-linking of collagen and elastin, leading to matrix stiffening.  AGEs are also proinflammatory and profibrotic because they activate dedicated receptors on immune cells and fibroblasts.

Cellular and tissue events

These events lead to detrimental changes in cells and tissues.  There are 3 general outcomes:

  • Cell loss:  When injury outpaces repair, cells can adaptively shrink (atrophy) or undergo regulated death (apoptosis).  The impact is greatest in tissues with limited mitotic capacity, such as neurons, skeletal muscle, cardiac myocytes, nodal pacemaker cells, and nephrons.  When lost, these cells are normally replaced by stem or progenitor cells.  With aging, however, stem cells progressively lose their self-renewal capacity (stemness) because of accumulated DNA damage, mitochondrial dysfunction, and proteostatic stress.
  • Cell senescence:  Not all damaged cells undergo apoptosis or atrophy.  Many become senescent, a state of permanent cell cycle arrest that functions as a cancer safeguard by halting further division.  Senescence can be triggered by repeated cellular injury, activation of oncogenes, or, simply, attainment of the natural replication limit (eg, telomere shortening).  Although it is protective against malignant transformation, senescence comes at a cost: Senescent cells accumulate with age and secrete a mixture of proinflammatory chemokines, profibrotic factors, and proteases known as the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which degrades surrounding tissue and impairs the function of nearby healthy cells (
    figure 1
    ).
  • Malignancy:  As mutations accumulate, some cells progress from dysplasia to neoplasia.  Normally, such cells are eliminated through DNA damage checkpoints and immune surveillance.  With aging, however, these safeguards are weakened, increasing the risk of cancer.

The ECM also changes.  AGE cross-links stiffen collagen and elastin, elastic fibers fragment, and profibrotic signaling from the SASP promotes collagen deposition.  In some tissues, misfolded proteins deposit as amyloid (eg, transthyretin in myocardium and tendons).  These processes collectively reduce compliance and elasticity (eg, diastolic dysfunction, decreased bladder capacity, decreased tendon and joint range of motion).

Organ systems

Normal aging produces relatively predictable changes across all organ systems.  These changes can overlap with mechanisms of disease and may someday prove modifiable by reversing the molecular and cellular lesions previously discussed.  This section highlights expected patterns of aging to help distinguish typical trajectories from clinically concerning pathology.

Neurologic/cognitive

Normal aging brings gradual neuronal atrophy that affects gray matter (cell bodies) more than white matter (myelinated axons).  Whole brain volume typically shrinks by 0.5% per year after midlife, accelerating after age 65.

  • Gray matter volume loss is diffuse but tends to be greatest in the hippocampi (responsible for new learning and long-term memory) and frontoparietal association cortices (responsible for executive function and working memory).  As a result, cognitively normal older adults usually have preserved knowledge and vocabulary but struggle more with recalling recent conversations, multitasking, and making complex decisions.
  • White matter hyperintensities accumulate due to chronic small vessel ischemia, leading to slowed communication between brain regions.  One consequence is the classic hesitant, or magnetic, gait of an older individual due to impaired relay from intention to movement.  This arises because conduction slows from the premotor cortex (planning), through the periventricular white matter tracts, and to the motor cortex (execution).

Although cemented abilities such as vocabulary and general knowledge remain intact, processing and retrieval speed is reduced (ie, accurate but slower).  Mild cognitive impairment is not considered part of the normal aging spectrum because it requires an absolute deficit (eg, ‚â§25/30 [normal: ‚â•26] on Montreal Cognitive Assessment) (

üìä View Table: table 1
).  Brain imaging often shows modest cortical thinning with slightly widened sulci (deeper grooves).  Mild ventricular enlargement is common and remains proportional to the degree of atrophy, unlike the more extensive dilation seen with normal pressure hydrocephalus (disproportionate) (
image 2
).

The aging brain is also more vulnerable to acute dysfunction.  Stressors such as illness, sleep disruption, anticholinergic medications, or unfamiliar environments can precipitate delirium, an acute confusional state with fluctuating attention and alertness.  Sleep provides restorative protection, but aging is associated with changes in sleep architecture (eg, less slow-wave [N3] and REM sleep, more arousals) that blunt the brain's recovery capacity.

Visual

Normal aging produces characteristic ocular changes that affect the cornea, lens, anterior chamber, vitreous, and retina (

üìä View Table: table 2
).

  • The cornea flattens slightly due to decreased epithelial cell density and loss of aquaporin function, leading to a mild refractive error.  Corneal sensitivity decreases, which can predispose to abrasions.  Peripheral lipid deposition (arcus senilis) is common and usually benign in older adults (vision sparing).  Lacrimal gland function decreases, leading to evaporative dry eye.
  • The lens thickens and becomes more rigid due to glycation and cross-linking, leading to a decreased ability to focus on near objects (eg, presbyopia) because the ciliary body has more difficulty bending the lens.  Progressive nuclear sclerosis (cataract) scatters incoming light, diminishing contrast and increasing glare and halos (eg, seen when driving at night).  Blue color perception declines due to mild lens yellowing from oxidation of lens proteins (crystallins).
  • In the anterior chamber, aqueous outflow through the trabecular meshwork declines modestly with age, leading to a slight rise in intraocular pressure.  Although this is usually benign, it increases the risk of primary open-angle glaucoma, an important cause of preventable vision loss.
  • The vitreous is a uniform gel comprising water, collagen, and hyaluronic acid.  With aging, the gel completely liquifies in certain areas (eg, lacunae).  Precipitated collagen fibrils form visible strands (eg, floaters).  Stress is not uniformly distributed, leading to traction on the retina, increasing the risk of detachment, tears, and macular holes.
  • The retina exhibits photoreceptor loss, predominantly of rod cells (eg, impaired night vision and slower adjustment to dim light).  The retinal epithelium accumulates lipofuscin and drusen, focal, plaque-like protein deposits that contribute to age-related macular degeneration.

Most age-related ocular changes (mild refractive shifts, presbyopia, glare, slower dark adaptation) are considered normal and usually do not threaten vision.  Cataracts are the leading cause of reversible visual impairment worldwide, and age-related macular degeneration is the main cause of central vision loss.

Auditory

Presbycusis is the most common cause of age-related hearing loss (

üìä View Table: table 3
).  It is a bilateral, symmetric, sensorineural decline that progresses slowly over decades.  It stems from the degeneration of cochlear hair cells and neurons, especially those detecting high frequencies; therefore, older patients often struggle with consonant discrimination ("s," "t," "f") and speech in noisy environments, increasing reliance on lip-reading.  Unlike conductive losses (eg, cerumen impaction), presbycusis does not improve with louder volume but can respond to hearing aids.  Hearing loss in older adults is linked to isolation, depression, and greater cognitive decline, underscoring the need for early recognition and treatment.

Cardiovascular

Normal aging leads to changes in the vasculature, valves, heart muscle, conduction system, and autonomics (

üìä View Table: Physiologic agerelated cardiovascular changes resultant clinical manifestations
):

  • Large arteries stiffen as medial elastin is degraded and collagen is cross-linked.  Functionally, this produces systolic hypertension because the arteries dissipate pulse energy less effectively.  The aortic leaflets frequently develop calcification, termed aortic sclerosis (ie, no significant gradient).  In some patients, this progresses to calcific aortic stenosis (eg, elevated gradient, symptoms).
  • The left ventricle adapts to the increased vascular stiffness and afterload by undergoing concentric hypertrophy, often with interstitial fibrosis, leading to a smaller cavity size and diastolic dysfunction (ie, impaired filling pressure but preserved ejection).  Fibrosis can also degrade the conduction system, predisposing to sinus node dysfunction, atrioventricular block, and bundle branch blocks.  The left atrium often enlarges due to diastolic dysfunction (higher filling pressure) and fibrosis, predisposing to atrial fibrillation.  The term "presbycardia" is sometimes used to describe this constellation of changes (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Autonomic responsiveness decreases, so maximal heart rate (HRmax) falls (eg, HRmax ‚âà 220 ‚àí age) and baroreceptor reflexes are blunted (eg, orthostatic hypotension with alpha-blockers, tricyclic antidepressants, and other medications)

Resting cardiac output is generally preserved with healthy aging, but maximal cardiac output decreases due to lower HRmax and blunted stroke volume reserve (~20%-30% lower in older vs young adults).

Respiratory

Normal aging leads to several changes in respiratory mechanics (

figure 3
):

The lung parenchyma loses elastic recoil due to elastin degradation and alveolar septal loss over time.  As a result, small airways collapse earlier during expiration, leading to mild airtrapping (eg, increased residual volume [RV]).  However, overall lung size (total lung capacity [TLC]) remains relatively constant after age 25.  Therefore, vital capacity, the difference between TLC and RV, steadily decreases by roughly 30 mL/year on spirometry (

figure 4
).

Earlier airway closure causes microatelectasis (ie, invisible on standard chest imaging), whereas age-related alveolar septal loss modestly reduces surface area and capillary blood volume.  Together, microatelectasis and surface loss lead to slightly decreased oxygen transfer, reflected by a mild decrease in the diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide and an age-dependent increase in the alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient (eg, expected A-a gradient ‚âà age / 3 ‚âà age / 4 + 4).

Other functional changes include lower pulmonary reserve (eg, increased risk of respiratory failure with infection or anesthesia) and weakened cough and mucociliary clearance (eg, increased risk of aspiration and pneumonia).

Renal

Normal aging leads to a gradual loss of nephrons, with compensatory hypertrophy of remaining nephrons.  Renal atrophy is greater in the cortex (glomerulosclerosis) than in the medulla (tubulointerstitial fibrosis).

  • Renal blood flow falls by roughly 10% per decade starting in midlife due to rising glomerular resistance (eg, hyaline arteriolosclerosis, atherosclerosis, endothelial dysfunction).  As a result, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) declines by approximately 10 mL/min/1.73 m2 per decade, with wide variability (
    figure 5
    ).
  • Decline in tubular functions leads to impaired concentrating and diluting capacity, which predisposes patients with poor oral intake to dehydration.  Reduced ammoniagenesis increases the risk of metabolic acidosis under stress.  Renin and aldosterone levels decrease, raising the risk of hyperkalemia (eg, with ACE inhibitors).

Because muscle mass also decreases with aging, serum creatinine can remain apparently normal despite a significant reduction in GFR.  Generally, creatinine-based estimated GFR overestimates renal function, especially in older patients with sarcopenia.  Drugs cleared by urinary excretion are prone to accumulating and may require more careful titration (eg, digoxin, metformin).

Genitourinary/pelvic

Normal aging alters bladder function, outlet resistance, and pelvic support.

  • Bladder capacity falls due to wall stiffening (eg, increased collagen).  Simultaneously, the detrusor muscle weakens, so postvoid residuals increase and patients are at increased risk for acute urinary retention, especially when using medications with anticholinergic activity (eg, antihistamines).  Retention affects men more than women, due to concurrent outlet resistance from prostatic hyperplasia.  With high retained volumes, overflow incontinence can occur (eg, dribbling).
  • At the same time, detrusor activity increases, leading to sensations of urgency.  An effective on-demand continence response depends on healthy periventricular white matter (for rapid control), mobility (to get to the toilet), and strength of pelvic floor muscles, including the urethral sphincter.  These are compromised in older patients, leading to urge incontinence.
  • In women, pelvic floor laxity and reduced urethral closure (from postmenopausal atrophy) predispose to stress incontinence (eg, leakage with exercise, laughter, or sneezing).  Pelvic organ prolapse can also cause physical obstruction and overflow incontinence.
  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria is common (~20% at random) due to urinary stasis and decreased mucosal immunity.  This generally does not require treatment by itself but can predispose patients to episodes of symptomatic bacterial cystitis.

Gastrointestinal

Normal aging leads to decreased gastrointestinal motility and altered oral drug metabolism; however, absorptive and secretory function largely remains intact.

  • In the upper gastrointestinal tract, oropharyngeal swallowing becomes less coordinated (presbyphagia) due to periventricular white matter disease (eg, coordination), muscle weakness (eg, tongue, pharynx), and impaired mastication (eg, poor dentition).  The esophagus becomes less peristaltic, hiatal hernia (eg, crural muscle weakening) is more common, and the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes; these changes predispose to gastroesophageal reflux and pill esophagitis.
  • Gastric acidity and small bowel absorption capacity are generally preserved.  Pancreatic exocrine function is generally preserved (eg, maintaining absorption of proteins and fats).  Gallbladder contractility decreases and bile acid cholesterol content increases, favoring biliary sludging and cholelithiasis.
  • Hepatic drug metabolism changes, mainly due to decreased liver blood flow (
    üìä View Table: table 5
    ).  First-pass metabolism decreases, leading to higher oral bioavailability of certain medications (eg, morphine, propranolol, verapamil), which may result in greater sedation or hypotension at a given dose.  Conversely, clearance (eg, cytochrome oxidase activity) decreases, which prolongs drug half-life.
  • Colonic motility slows and is worsened by low physical activity or constipating drugs (eg, anticholinergics, calcium channel blockers, iron).  At the same time, the rectal sphincter weakens, so stool retention can paradoxically lead to leakage (overflow fecal incontinence).

Dysphagia, weight loss, iron deficiency anemia, and malabsorption are not features of normal aging and should prompt diagnostic evaluation.

Endocrine/metabolic

With normal aging, basal hormone levels are often near normal except for androgens and estrogens.  However, deficits are more easily unmasked by stressors such as acute illness.

  • Glucose:  Visceral adiposity rises and lean mass falls, producing insulin resistance.  In addition, early-phase (meal-stimulated) insulin release is blunted, leading to higher postprandial glucose despite normal fasting levels.  Counterregulation to hypoglycemia (eg, glucagon, cortisol, and catecholamine response) is weaker, predisposing patients to hypoglycemia with fasting, illness, or antidiabetic medications.
  • Thyroid axis:  With age, tissue 5‚Ä≤-deiodinase activity gradually declines, so conversion of T4 (prohormone) to T3 (active hormone) becomes less efficient.  As a result, serum T3 levels slowly fall, whereas free T4 levels generally remain stable.  TSH can drift upward due to a reset in the hypothalamic-pituitary feedback setpoint.  This combination creates a laboratory picture that resembles subclinical hypothyroidism (ie, mildly elevated TSH, normal T4) but represents an aging-related change in normal value limits rather than true thyroid disease.  It usually does not warrant treatment because the adverse effects of thyroid hormone supplementation (eg, atrial fibrillation, bone loss) outweigh the benefits.
  • Adrenal axis:  The diurnal cortisol rhythm flattens (ie, peaks are lower, troughs are higher), yet maximal output to stress is usually preserved.  In contrast, dehydroepiandrosterone declines steadily, reducing the availability of androgen precursors.
  • Gonadal axis:  In women, menopause brings a permanent decline in ovarian estrogen and progesterone production, leading to vasomotor symptoms, bone loss, and genitourinary atrophy.  Vasomotor symptoms can last for an average of 7-10 years after the final menstrual period.  In men, free testosterone falls due to testicular atrophy, which is associated with changes in energy, perceived wellness, and muscle mass.
  • Bone mineral axis:  Cutaneous vitamin D synthesis declines due to epidermal thinning, reduced perfusion, and depletion of precursor steroids.  In parallel, renal 1-alpha hydroxylation and intestinal calcium absorption also decline.  These changes can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism (especially with underlying chronic kidney disease), tilting the bone balance toward resorption.  The result is progressive bone mineral loss (~1% per year in men, >2% per year in women).

Hematologic

Bone marrow cellularity declines with age as hematopoietic cells are progressively replaced by fat (eg, marrow cellularity % ‚âà 100 ‚àí age).

  • Erythropoiesis (formation of red blood cells) falls modestly, resulting in mild normocytic anemia.  Because of fibrofatty replacement, the marrow is less responsive to erythropoietin, so circulating erythropoietin generally rises with aging.  In addition, iron is less bioavailable due to elevated hepcidin (upregulated by chronic inflammation).  Superimposed illness can unmask anemia easily.
  • Myelopoiesis (formation of white blood cells) is generally preserved.  However, immune cells have qualitative immunologic defects (discussed in the next section).
  • Thrombopoiesis (platelets) remains intact with age, with stable platelet and megakaryocyte counts.  However, platelet reactivity increases, particularly in response to prothrombotic stimuli (eg, infection, inflammation), leading to an increased risk of acute cardiovascular events during stress.

In addition, many older adults develop a degree of clonal hematopoiesis due to age-acquired mutations in precursor cells.  This state is usually asymptomatic, but it carries a higher risk of hematologic malignancy (eg, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, myelodysplastic syndrome).

Immunologic

Normal aging is associated with immunosenescence, affecting both innate and adaptive defenses.

  • With respect to innate immunity, neutrophils, natural killer (NK) cells, and macrophages remain quantitatively intact, but their function declines.  Neutrophils and macrophages exhibit reduced chemotaxis, phagocytosis, and microbial killing (eg, weaker respiratory burst), whereas NK cells show diminished cytotoxicity.  Older adults often have a blunted systemic inflammatory response due to the decreased production of acute phase cytokines.  Fever, leukocytosis, and tachycardia may be muted or absent during infection.
  • In terms of adaptive immunity, both T and B cells are affected.  Thymic involution begins in late childhood and continues until death.  By age 70, the thymus is reduced to approximately 10% of its original size, leaving little capacity to quickly generate new T cells.  Older adults therefore rely heavily on memory T-cell pools, which limits their ability to respond to novel antigens.  B-cell function also declines, partly due to a lack of T-cell assistance.  Serum total immunoglobulin levels are generally preserved, but the ability to produce high-affinity antibodies is reduced.  Together, these changes underlie diminished vaccine responsiveness, greater susceptibility to infectious disease (eg, pneumonia, influenza), and reactivation of latent viruses (eg, varicella-zoster virus).

Musculoskeletal

Normal aging alters bone, muscle, and connective tissue.

  • Bone skews toward resorption, as previously described, increasing the risk of osteopenia, osteoporosis, and fragility fractures.
  • Skeletal muscle atrophies with age, with fast-twitch (type II) fibers being most affected.  This compromises the body's ability to make rapid and powerful postural adjustments, which are essential for maintaining balance.  The Timed Up and Go (TUG) test (rise from chair, walk 3 m [10 ft], turn, and sit back down as quickly as possible) can often capture this deficit.  Sarcopenia is defined as a measurable age-related reduction in muscle power (eg, on the TUG test), muscle, or both.
  • Cartilage and tendons accumulate cross-links (eg, AGE, amyloid) and microdamage, whereas intervertebral discs dehydrate and lose height, producing degenerative joint disease and spinal stiffness.

Together, these changes impair mobility, balance, and motor power, raising the risk of falls and fractures.

Dermatologic

Skin is among the most visible markers of aging.

  • Epidermal turnover slows, and dermal fibroblasts produce less collagen and elastin, leading to thinning, dryness, and impaired wound healing.  Melanocyte density decreases (eg, to <25% of youthful levels by age 70), producing graying hair and hypopigmented macules.  However, benign focal proliferations of melanocytes can cause lentigines (liver spots).
  • Elastic fiber fragmentation and hyaluronan degradation lead to laxity and wrinkles.  Subcutaneous fat is lost in some areas (face, hands, shins) but redistributed in others, resulting in sagging and predisposing to pressure injury.  Senile (solar) purpura, which is characterized by intermittent ecchymotic lesions primarily on the hands and forearms, arises due to blood vessel fragility after years of sun-related damage to the dermis; platelet counts and coagulation tests are typically normal.
  • Immune surveillance declines (fewer Langerhans cells [skin macrophages] and reduced cutaneous T-cell function), making it easier for ultraviolet damage to induce actinic keratoses, basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.

Summary

Aging is driven by the gradual accumulation of molecular and cellular damage that leads to irreversible loss of organ function and reserve (

üìä View Table: table 6
).  At the molecular level, genomic instability, mitochondrial dysfunction, proteostatic stress, and extracellular matrix cross-linking underlie much of the decline.  At the cellular level, apoptosis, senescence, and diminished stem cell renewal translate into progressive organ system vulnerability.  Clinically, these changes manifest as predictable patterns:

  • Cognitive aging typically produces slower processing and retrieval but preserves knowledge, vocabulary, and independence in daily activities.
  • Visual aging brings presbyopia (difficulty with near focus), increased glare, cataracts, and risk of macular degeneration and glaucoma.
  • Auditory aging manifests as presbycusis (high-frequency hearing loss and impaired speech discrimination), which can lead to increased social isolation and cognitive decline.
  • Cardiovascular changes include arterial stiffening, diastolic dysfunction, conduction disease, and diminished maximal heart rate and cardiac output reserve.
  • Respiratory aging involves the loss of lung elastin, leading to gradually elevated residual volume and loss of vital capacity.
  • Renal aging involves a progressive decline in glomerular filtration rate, which often occurs despite stable serum creatinine levels (due to decreased muscle mass).
  • Bladder and pelvic floor changes predispose to incontinence, retention, and asymptomatic bacteriuria.
  • Endocrine and metabolic adaptations include insulin resistance and mild subclinical changes in thyroid hormone profile.
  • Hematologic and immune changes decrease hematopoiesis (fatty replacement of the bone marrow), diminish vaccine response, and increase infection and malignancy risk.
  • Musculoskeletal aging involves sarcopenia, bone loss, and connective tissue cross-linking, which, together, reduce strength and range of motion, increasing fall and fracture risk.

Distinguishing normal aging from pathologic disease is critical to avoiding both overtreatment and undertreatment, especially because some features overlap with clinical disorders.
